definitions.definition: To dislodge or remove (someone) from a seat , especially on horseback .
examples: The frightened horse reared up and unseated its rider.
I was unseated from my bike after hitting an unexpected pothole.

subdefinitions.definition: To remove (someone) from an office or position , especially a political one; to dethrone .
examples: After having lost her seat to a Tory, she succeeded in unseating him in the next general election.
India has recently unseated China as the world’s most populous country.

subdefinitions.definition: To cause (something) to be removed or replaced in its role ; to displace , to overturn .
examples: The Michelson-Morley experiment prompted scientists to unseat their belief in the luminiferous aether .
Printed newspapers are gradually being unseated by digital publications.

subdefinitions.definition: To upset the composure of (someone); to astound , to shock , to unsettle .
examples: The Matrix (1999) utterly unseated audiences around the world with its mind-blowing plot twist.
I was somewhat unseated by the strange noises outside my window.

definitions.definition: To come off or out of a seat.
examples: We replaced the screws, since the old ones unseated too easily.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To dislodge or remove (someone) from a seat , especially on horseback .
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive , technical ) To come off or out of a seat.
